question: Question_01_(a)
statement:
Answer the following multiple choice question. Check your answer very
carefully. Your answer will be marked right or wrong (work will not be
considered for this problem).

Does the sum

\begin{align*}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac {n^{0.1}} {n^{0.99}+n^{1.1}+1}\end{align*} converge?

A. Converge.

B. Diverge.
sols:
The difference between the highest exponents is 1.1-0.1 = 1. By the
series \emph{p} test (with \emph{p} = 1) this series \textbf{diverges}.

More precisely we can prove

$\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{n^{0.1}}{n^{0.99} + n^{1.1}+1} > \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{n^{0.1}}{n^{1.1} + n^{1.1} + n^{1.1}} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac{n^{0.1}}{3n^{1.1}} = \frac13\sum_{n=1}^\infty\frac1n=\infty$

The last sum diverges because of the series \emph{p} test with
\emph{p=1}.
hints:
If you do not see a possibility to use the series \emph{p} test, try to
estimate the sum downstairs.
